unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Refer to the Formula
question_text: Which of the following represents the variance when completing a $z$-test for the difference between two population proportions?

choices.text: $n(p)(1-p)$ where $p$ is the observed proportion of successes from both populations combined.

$\dfrac { \left( { p }_{ 1 } \right) \left( 1 -{ p }_{ 1 } \right) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { \left( { p }_{ 2 } \right) \left( 1 - { p }_{ 2 } \right) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } $ where ${ p }_{ 1 }$ is the hypothesized proportion for population $1$ and ${ p }_{ 2 }$ is the hypothesized proportion for population $2$.

$\dfrac { \left( \hat { { p }_{ 1 } } \right) \left( 1 -\hat { { p }_{ 1 } } \right) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { \left( \hat { { p }_{ 2 } } \right) \left( 1 - \hat { { p }_{ 2 } } \right) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } $ where $\hat { { p }_{ 1 } } $ is the observed proportion from population $1$ and $\hat { { p }_{ 2} }$ is the observed proportion from population $2$ .
$\left( p \right) \left( 1 - p \right) \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 2 } } \right) $ where $p$ is the observed proportion from both populations combined.

solution:
The reference materials provided with the A. P. Exam give formulas for the standard deviation of a statistic in both single-sample and two-sample situations.

Formula 1

Here, we are dealing with the difference of two sample proportions. Two formulas for this situation are provided. The first formula is:

$$\sqrt{\dfrac { \left( { p }_{ 1 } \right) \left( 1 -{ p }_{ 1 } \right) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { \left( { p }_{ 2 } \right) \left( 1 - { p }_{ 2 } \right) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } }$$

It is up to you to know that ${ p }_{ 1 }$ represents the proportion from population $1$ and ${ p }_{ 2 }$ represents the proportion from population $2$. Also, ${ n }_{ 1 }$ represents the sample size taken from population $1$ and ${ n }_{ 2 }$ represents the sample size taken from population $2$.

Formula 2

The second formula given is for the special case when $p_1 = p_2$. This formula is:

$$\sqrt{\left( p \right) \left( 1 - p \right) }\sqrt{\left( \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 2 } } \right) }$$

Notice that in this formula, there are no subscripts attached to $p$. That is because in this case, $p$ represents the pooled (combined) proportion of successes from both samples. That is:

$$p=\dfrac{\text{the total number of successes from both samples combined}}{\text{the total number of observations in both samples combined}}$$
.

When conducting a test for a difference between two sample proportions, we assume $p_1 = p_2$ as our null hypothesis. Therefore, the second formula given in the reference material (and shown above) is the appropriate formula to use â€“ for calculating standard deviation, that is.

To find the variance however, we simply square the standard deviation. Therefore, the correct variance is:

$$\left( p \right) \left( 1 - p \right) \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 2 } } \right) $$

The correct answer is Choice 'E'.

Reminder: Sadly, $p$ has a lot of different meanings in statistics. It can refer to the probability of success in a binomial situation, the true population proportion (the parameter) in a single-sample situation involving a population proportion, the $p$-value that results from conducting a statistical test, and in this case the combined proportion from two independent samples. Some texts also refer to ${p}^{*}$ as being a guessed value for the population proportion when trying to determine the appropriate sample size. This makes it extremely important to be aware of the different possible meanings of $p$ and to be alert to the context and details in each specific problem.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. It represents the standard deviation of a sample mean and is used when calculating a $z$-statistic in a test (or confidence interval) for a population mean.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. This is the formula for finding the variance in a binomial distribution where $n$ is the fixed number of observations and $p$ is the probability of success.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. When completing a test for a difference between two proportions, we do not make any hypothesis about the true proportion for population $1$ or the true proportion for population $2$. We don't know either of these two proportions either.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. This answer would be correct if we were constructing a confidence interval for a difference between two proportions. Since we do not know either population proportion, as part of constructing a confidence interval, we use the sample proportions as estimates instead.
